section: Heritage shall within [***] after the end of the production run, notify Premier via email of the final estimated production quantity and the estimated quantity, including losses, of all Premier-supplied materials used. If the final production quantity for any accepted PO is less than [***] of the PO quantity ordered, or if the quantity of production released for shipment within [***] from the last day of production is less than [***] of the PO quantity, upon request by Premier, Heritage *may* take commercially reasonable steps to produce or replace the shortfall within [***], *contingent upon Heritage's then-current production schedule and material availability, as reasonably determined by Heritage*.
explanation: The use of 'may' followed by the contingency significantly weakens Heritage's obligation to address production shortfalls. While Heritage *may* take steps to rectify the situation, it is only *contingent* on their current schedule and material availability. This creates ambiguity as to whether Heritage is truly obligated to remedy shortfalls or if they can simply decline based on their own internal factors. The phrasing is not strong enough to define the responsibilities of Heritage to replace any shortfalls.

section: Heritage shall bear all costs, fees and out-of-pocket expenses associated with any Recall Action which results from (i) Heritages or Jaspers negligence or willful misconduct, (ii) Heritages or Jaspers failure to comply with Product Specifications or the Post Holdings Quality Expectations Manual set forth on Schedule A, (iii) any breach of this Agreement by Heritage or (iv) ingredients or packaging materials purchased by Heritage or Jasper. In all other cases, Premier shall bear all costs associated with any Recall Action.
explanation: The phrase 'In all other cases, Premier shall bear all costs associated with any Recall Action' is too broad. It could be interpreted to mean that even if a recall is due to a defect in Premier's own formula or specifications (which they provide), Premier would still bear the costs if it doesn't fall under Heritage's negligence, non-compliance, breach, or faulty materials. This seems contradictory to the general principle that a party should be responsible for issues arising from their own contributions.

section: Heritage agrees to disclose to Premier and provide a list, upon request, of any material violations or deficiencies noted during any inspection by the FDA, United States Department of Agriculture, PHS, or any other federal, state or local health or food regulatory agency of the Heritage Facilities, Jasper Facility or any other Facility used to produce the Products, which have a material adverse effect on the manufacture or packaging of the Products.
explanation: The phrase 'which have a material adverse effect on the manufacture or packaging of the Products' introduces ambiguity. What constitutes a 'material adverse effect' is subjective and open to interpretation. This allows Heritage to potentially withhold information about violations that they deem not to have a material adverse effect, even if Premier might disagree.

section: Premier shall have the sole right, exercisable in its discretion, to initiate and direct the content and scope of a recall, market withdrawal, stock recovery, product correction and/or advisory safety communication (any one or more referred to as a Recall Action) regarding the Products. At Premiers option, Premier can direct Heritage to, and upon such direction Heritage shall, conduct such Recall Action (and Heritage shall ensure Jaspers cooperation).
explanation: While Premier has the 'sole right' to initiate a recall, they can also 'direct Heritage to conduct' the recall. This raises a question about the extent of Heritage's liability and autonomy. If Premier directs a recall that Heritage believes is unnecessary or improperly scoped, Heritage is still obligated to carry it out. This could lead to disputes about the appropriateness and cost of recall actions.
